Hypoxia induces tachycardia when oxygen concentration is lower than 17%. Tachycardia caused by hypoxia is due to?

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) are produced in the colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, and other dietary components that could not be digested in the small intestine. (like dietary fibres-60% of the total is acetate, 25% propionate, 15% butyrate). These short-chain fatty acids are absorbed from the colon. SCFAs have trophic effect on colonic epithelial cells, they also combat inflammation and maintain acid-base equilibrium. SCFAs are not only a source of energy but also signaling molecules for the local regulation of the GI tract and systemic regulation via release of gut hormones. Targeting SCFA signals may be a novel therapeutic for GI diseases and metabolic syndrome.

questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Name Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN)
Definition A form of acute kidney injury (AKI) characterized by a rapid decline in kidney function after the administration of contrast media used in medical imaging procedures.
Risk Factors 1. Pre-existing kidney disease. 2. Diabetes mellitus. 3. Hypertension. 4. Dehydration. 5. High doses of contrast media. 6. Multiple contrast exposures.
Contrast Media Iodinated contrast agents used in procedures like CT scans, angiography, and coronary angiography.
Mechanism The exact cause is not fully understood, but it involves a combination of factors, including vasoconstriction, oxidative stress, and direct toxicity to kidney cells.
Symptoms CIN may result in: 1. Increased serum creatinine levels. 2. Decreased urine output. 3. Fluid retention.
Diagnosis Based on an increase in serum creatinine levels within 48-72 hours after contrast exposure.
Prevention 1. Identifying high-risk patients. 2. Hydration before and after contrast procedures (e.g., intravenous saline). 3. Using low-osmolar or iso-osmolar contrast media. 4. Limiting contrast dose when possible.
Treatment Management is primarily supportive and includes ensuring adequate hydration and monitoring kidney function. Dialysis is rarely required.

Lab analysis shows an elevated level of antibodies against dsDNA. A diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus is made. Which of the following is least likely to be decreased in expression?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by the immune system's attack on various organs and tissues in the body.
Prevalence More common in females, especially during childbearing years. Higher prevalence in certain ethnic groups (e.g., African American, Hispanic, Asian).
Etiology Complex and not fully understood, but it involves genetic, environmental, and hormonal factors.
Clinical Manifestations Wide range of symptoms, including joint pain, skin rashes (often triggered by sun exposure), fatigue, fever, kidney problems, heart issues, and neurological symptoms.
Diagnostic Criteria Diagnosed based on a combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination, and laboratory tests. Common diagnostic criteria include the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) criteria.
Autoantibodies Common autoantibodies include anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm, anti-Ro, and anti-La antibodies.
Renal Involvement Lupus nephritis is a common and serious complication, leading to kidney damage.
Skin Involvement Butterfly rash (malar rash) across the cheeks and nose, photosensitivity, and skin lesions are common.
Joint Involvement Arthritis with joint pain and swelling can occur.
Cardiovascular Involvement May lead to heart inflammation (pericarditis) and increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
Neurological Involvement May cause cognitive dysfunction, seizures, or psychiatric symptoms.
Treatment Individualized treatment plans based on the severity of symptoms, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, immunosuppressive drugs, and biologics.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male complained of generalized fatigue associated with difficulty breathing. On examination, pallor & gingival hypertrophy is noted. Initial investigations revealed hyperleukocytosis. Follow-up investigations showed leukostasis. This feature is most predominantly seen in which of the following disorders?

A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib , and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes . What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Accelerated phase of CML

The patient is considered to be in accelerated phase if any of the following are true:

  • The blood samples have 15% or more but fewer than 30% blasts.
  • Basophils make up 20% or more of the blood cells.
  • Blasts and promyelocytes combined makeup 30% or more of the blood.
  • Very low platelet counts (100 x 1,000/cubic meter or less) that are not caused by treatment.
  • New chromosomes changes in the leukaemic cells with the Philadelphia chromosomes

Treatment options are as follows:

  • Patients who present with or evolve to blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • Patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase or patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response).
  • The most effective is stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: A woman presents with secondary amenorrhea of 4 months duration. She also complains of milk discharge from bilateral breasts. The investigation you should advise apart from serum prolactin levels is:

questions.explanation:
11 beta-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Androgen excess- masculinization of female newborns and precocious puberty in male
  • Hypertension, which may or may not be associated with mineralocorticoid excess, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis
Liddle syndrome
  • AD, hypertension associated with low plasma renin activity, metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and normal to low levels of aldosterone
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Since ESRD will ensue in these patients, hyperkalemia will always be a feature of ADPKD
Gitelman syndrome
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Glucokinase catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose 6-phosphate with a K m for glucose of about 7mM. A 14-year-old girl comes to the outpatient department complaining of having a very depressing feeling and being short-tempered with a loss of appetite as her father died of liver failure one month back. She feels moody and won't join others, so she thinks about joining her father. The most likely diagnosis is:

ICD-10 suggests including anxious, preoccupied, or "dreamy" apathetic children whose problems are probably different also under Hyperkinetic disorders. Which of the following is not seen in a hyperkinetic child?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic criteria (according to the DSM-5) [9]

A

Pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity that is inconsistent with the developmental level of the individual

  • Inattention is characterized by £ 6 of the following in children or £ 5 of the following in adolescents and a
    • Poor attention to details at work/school
    • Difficulty sustaining attention during tasks
    • Does not listen when spoken to directly (e.g. distraction in the absence of an obvious interruption)
    • Inability to complete tasks/instructions at work/school (e.g., easily sidetracked)
    • Struggles to organize tasks/activities (e.g. disorganized work, misses deadlines)
    • Prefers to avoid tasks that require a high amount of mental effort (e.g., homework, preparing reports)
    • Loses things necessary to complete tasks (e.g., stationery, documents)
    • Easily distracted
    • Forgetful (e.g., does not pay bills, does not do homework)
  • Hyperactivity and impulsivity are characterized by £ 6 of the following in children or £ 5 of the following
    • Fidgets or squirms in seat
    • Often leaves their seat during inappropriate situations (e.g. during meetings or in class)
    • Restless (runs about in inappropriate situations)
    • Unable to carry out tasks quietly
    • Talks excessively
    • Answers questions prematurely or for others
    • Difficulty waiting their turn (e.g. has problems with lines)
    • Interrupts other people (e.g., in conversation, during activities)

B

Several symptoms are present at < 12  years of age.

C

Symptoms are present in ≥ 2 settings (e.g., school, home, work). 

D

Symptoms interfere with important levels of functioning (e.g. school, work). 

E

Symptoms are not due to a mental disorder.

Type of emphysema

Parts of acinus involved

Region of lung

Causes

Centriacinar

Proximal parts of acini (respiratory bronchioles)

Upper lobes/Apical segments

Most common in cigarette smokers. Associated with chronic bronchitis.

Entire acinus

Lower zones and base of the lung

Associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Distal portion of acini

Adjacent to the pleura, along the connective tissue septa and margin of lobules.

More common in the upper half of the lungs.

questions.explanation:

Feature

Rigor mortis

Heat stiffening

Mechanism

Due to breakdown of ATP of muscles

Due to heat coagulation of muscle protein

Time of formation

2-12 h after death

Can be antemortem or postmortem

Role of heat

High temperature enhances the process

Occur at a temperature >65°C

Onset

In sequence

Rapid and diffuse

Degree of stiffness

Moderate

High

Mechanical pull at joints

Will revert to rigidity extension (if not fully developed)

External features

Nothing specific

In sequence, at various duration

Uniform, with onset of putrefaction

A 65-year-old male patient with previously good health presented to the emergency department with new testicular pain and swelling. Physical examination and ultrasonography revealed a large, heterogeneous, vascularized mass in the right scrotum. The patient underwent high inguinal orchidectomy, and histopathology showed that the mass had invaded the tunica albuginea and the epididymis. What is the disease stage?
questions.explanation:
T: Primary tumour

 

 N: Regional lymph nodes(Clinical)

 
pTis: Intratubular germ cell neoplasia (carcinoma in situ)

 

 N1: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes less than 2 cm in size

 
pT1: Limited to the testis & epididymis and no vascular/ lymphatic invasion; Tumor may invade tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

 

 N2: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes greater than 2 cm but less than 5 cm in size

 
pT2: Limited to the testis & epididymis with vascular/ lymphatic invasion or extending through tunica albuginea with involvement of tunica vaginalis

 

 N3: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes greater than 5 cm in size

 
pT3: Invades the spermatic cord with or without invading vascular/lymphatic

 

 M1: Distant metastases

 

M1a: Non-regional nodal or pulmonary metastases

M1b: Distant metastasis at a site other than non-regional lymph nodes or lung
pT4: Invades the scrotum with or without invading vascular/lymphatic

 

 Serum tumour markers (S)

 

S1 : LDH <1.5 x normal, hCG <5000 IU/L, AFP < 1000 ng/mL

S2 : LDH 1.5-10 x normal, hCG 5000 - 50000 IU/L, AFP 1000 - 10000 ng/mL

S3 : LDH >10 x normal, hCG >50000 IU/L, AFP >10000 ng/mL

He had a history of alcohol consumption for the last 25 years , with average daily consumption of more than 1 lit re of alcohol. An initial diagnosis of Wernicke's encephalopathy was made. After eating, he reports constant difficulty in swallowing; however, there are no other symptoms like nausea, vomiting, melena, or fever. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is done, which reveals a rough oesophagal mucosa, and large discrete ulcers are visible. The barium image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

He has been taken up for total hip Replacement by the surgeon. What is the most common complication which can lead to death in this patient?

A 38-year-old female presented in the outpatient department with a complaint of recurrent abdominal pain and constipation for two weeks. She has been experiencing these symptoms since adolescence, with periods of improvement and exacerbation. Over the past year, her symptoms have been occurring more frequently. On examination, she was a well-nourished woman in no acute distress . Her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure at 110/80 mmHg, pulse at 60 beats per minute, and respiratory rate at 12 breaths per minute. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS- constipation dominant) . Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?

A 59-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of a feeling of swollen and enlarged neck for the past month . The patient had no previous history of such swelling and no family history of thyroid-related disorders or other neoplasms. An endocrine examination showed that the patient was euthyroid, and there were no thyroid autoantibodies.On ultrasound, a diffusely enlarged left thyroid tumor showing a heterogenous pattern without clear capsule formation is seen in the cervical region . Which of the following is the best investigation for diagnosing this disease ?

A 75-year-old male, an elderly diabetic patient, is brought to the medical outpatient department by his daughter with complaints of altered mental status, headache, and nasal congestion. He has been suffering from these symptoms for a week now. He is also complaining of blurred vision. On examination, he has facial swelling on one side. On the chest X-ray, cavitary lesions are seen. The doctor orders a fungal screen. The biopsy showed LCB-stained periorbital exudates in severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis and showed obtuse angle branching aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Name Mucormycosis 
Type Fungal infection caused by Mucorales fungi, commonly belonging to the genera Rhizopus, Mucor, and others
Predisposing Factors - Immunocompromised state (transplant recipients, diabetes, cancer, HIV)- Trauma, burns, surgery
Routes of Infection Inhalation, ingestion, direct inoculation, including wounds and invasive medical procedures
Clinical Forms - Rhinocerebral (head and sinuses)- Pulmonary (lungs)- Cutaneous (skin)- Gastrointestinal
Symptoms - Facial pain, headache, nasal congestion (rhinocerebral)- Cough, chest pain, fever (pulmonary)
  - Skin lesions, ulcers (cutaneous)- Abdominal pain, vomiting (gastrointestinal)
Diagnosis - Clinical presentation- Imaging (CT, MRI)- Biopsy and histopathology- Microscopy
Treatment - Antifungal therapy (amphotericin B)- Surgical debridement of infected tissue- Control of risk factors
Prognosis Mortality rate varies based on the site of infection, underlying conditions, and timely treatment
Prevention - Strict blood sugar control in diabetes patients- Protective measures in high-risk patients
Epidemiology - Rare, but has gained attention due to recent cases during the COVID-19 pandemic

A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, rashes on the palms and sole of foot and headaches for 1 week. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. Which of the following is known to be the causative agent for Vincent's angina ?
A 7-year-old boy with abrupt onset of pain in hip with hip held in abduction. Hemogram is normal. ESR is raised. What is the next line of management?
questions.correct_answer: D. USG guided aspiration of hip
questions.explanation:
Urgent USG guided aspiration of hip is needed to examine the fluid and rule out septic arthritis . However lack of systamic symptoms like fever and and normal hemogram indicate towards Transient synovitis of hip.

TRANSIENT (TOXIC) SYNOVITIS OF HIP

  • It is self-limiting, inflammatory condition of synovium. It is common cause of hip pain and limping in children from 6 to 12 years of age.
  • Absence of fever and systemic illness
  • USG reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveal a WBC count between 5,000 and 15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • Aspiration should be done to rule out other causes of synovitis.
  • The primary aim of treatment is to expedite spontaneous resolution with brief period of bed rest and non-weight bearing, light traction and use of oral NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been brought to the clinic with fever and right leg pain for the last two days. Examination shows erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the femur. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation for detecting early bone infections?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ This patient with fever, erythema, swelling, tenderness of the femur, raised ESR, and leukocyte count most likely has osteomyelitis, an infection of the bone .
  • ↳ This patient with fever, erythema, swelling, tenderness of the femur, raised ESR, and leukocyte count most likely has osteomyelitis, an infection of the bone
  • ↳ Bone scan is next in preference to MRI to pick up infections by picking osteoblastic activity at the site of infection.
  • ↳ It has high sensitivity but low specificity.
  • ↳ Earliest and 100% surest investigation is Aspiration of pus.
  • ↳ Osteomyelitis :
  • ↳ Osteomyelitis
  • ↳ Osteomyelitis most commonly develops from transient, hematogenous dissemination of bacterial infection, which eventually seed in the bone. The bacteria continue to grow in the bone cavity, increasing the intramedullary pressure and causing necrosis of the overlying bone cortex. The bacteria then spread to the nearby tissue creating a localized swelling filled with bacteria, dead bone cells, and leukocytes. Evaluation of osteomyelitis includes bone biopsy and culture with imaging. Osteomyelitis can be detected in the early stages by MRI and bone scan. MRI shows a hyperintense area in the bone marrow, while the bone scan shows an area of increased osteoblast activity at the site of infection. X-ray is more valuable in the later stages to reveal the destruction of the cortex but can miss the early stages of the disease.

questions.text: Which among the following has the lowest resting membrane potential?
questions.explanation:
Cell Type Resting Membrane Potential (mV)
Neurons -70 to -90
Skeletal Muscle Cells -80 to -90
Cardiac Muscle Cells -80 to -90
Smooth Muscle Cells -50 to -60
Red Blood Cells -15 to -20

Definition Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the electrical potential difference across a cell membrane at rest.
Measured Voltage Typically measured in millivolts (mV).
Electrochemical Gradient Maintained by the unequal distribution of ions (sodium, potassium, chloride) across the cell membrane.
Ions Involved Sodium (Na⁺) and potassium (K⁺) ions are primary contributors to establishing RMP.
Ion Channels Channels responsible for RMP include leak channels (e.g., K⁺ leak channels) and Na⁺/K⁺ pumps.
Neurons' RMP -70 to -90 mV (inside the neuron is more negative compared to the outside).
Role in Excitability RMP is crucial for the initiation and propagation of action potentials (nerve impulses) in neurons.
Maintained by ATP Na⁺/K⁺ pumps actively transport ions against their electrochemical gradients, consuming ATP to maintain RMP.
Factors Influencing RMP Ion concentration gradients, permeability of the cell membrane to ions, activity of ion channels, and pumps.
Clinical Significance Changes in RMP can affect cell excitability and function, leading to various medical conditions and diseases.

questions.explanation:
Indicators used in the measurement of body fluids

1. Total body water (TBW)
  •  

Deuterium (D2O)

Tritium (3H2O)

Antipyrine

Aminopyrine

2. ECF volume:

Non-metabolizable saccharides are used

  •  
  • Inulin (best)
  • Sucrose
  • Mannitol
  • Sodium thiosulphate and Sodium thiocyanate are also used.

3. ICF volume

(TBW - ECF), can't be measured directly

4. Plasma volume

Iodine 125, Radio labelled albumin, Evans' blue(T1824)

5. Red cell volume

Tagging with 51Cr, Fe-59, 32P

6. Interstitial fluid

(ECF volume – Plasma volume.)

questions.explanation:
Screening test Diagnostic test
It is done on an apparently healthy individual It is done on those with indications or sick.
Applied to groups Applied to single patients: All diseases are considered in a diagnostic test
Test results are arbitrary and final Diagnosis is not final but modified in light of new evidence, diagnosis is the sum of all evidence.
Based on one criterion or cut-off point Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs (e.g., diabetes), and laboratory findings.
Less accurate: Less expensive; Not a basis for treatment More accurate: More expensive; Used as a basis of treatment
The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care. The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint.

questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Location Along the length of the spinal cord within the subarachnoid space
Structure Thin, triangular ligamentous extensions composed of pia mater
Attachments - Extend from the spinal cord's pia mater to the dura mater
  - Attach along the lateral margins of the spinal cord to the inner surface of the dura mater
Function Provides structural support and stabilization to the spinal cord within the vertebral canal
  Helps anchor the spinal cord, preventing excessive movement
  Prevents lateral movement of the spinal cord during head and body movements
Clinical Significance Important landmarks for segmental levels of the spinal cord
  Can assist in determining the appropriate site for lumbar punctures or spinal anesthesia

questions.text: What is type IIIA in the Nyhus classification of hernias?
questions.explanation:
Nyhus classification system
Type I Indirect hernia; internal ring normal: typically, in infants, children, and young adults.
Type II Indirect hernia: internal ring enlarged without impingement on the floor of the inguinal canal: does not extend to be scrotum.
Type IIIA Direct hernia (size is not taken into account).
Type IIIB Indirect hernia enlarged enough to infringe upon the posterior inguinal wall; indirect sliding or scrotal hernias and pantaloon hernias.
Type IIIC Femoral hernia
Type IV A Direct recurrent hernia
Type IV B Indirect recurrent hernia
Type IV C Femoral recurrent hernia
Type IV D Combined recurrent hernia
